comments.commentBody:
This incomplete account of Rolland Oliphant that the Russian aid convoy saying it is is an "escalation of the conflict" is misleading. In his article in The Telegraph the contents are described as "Two trucks, chosen at random by The Telegraph, proved to contain sacks of buckwheat and cardboard boxes full of sleeping bags – exactly the kind of aid Russia has always insisted it is sending over the border." SEE http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11035627/Dispat...
Let's not return to the 1950s when anything Russian was evil.
The tanks, artillery and aircraft the Kiev controlled army is using to kill Ukrainian citizens can't be hidden in trucks.
It's also one of the most strategic ports in all of south central Europe

Shaun Walker from the Guardian now reports that the advance of a Russian military column into the Ukrainian territory does not appear to be a full scale invasion, just one of those frequent incursions that the Ukrainian government has been talking about.  Now the humanitarian convoy has stopped.  If anyone is confused, they have every reason to be.  I think even those who direct all  the charade are confused.  My theory is that Putin is dancing a complicated maneuver.  He appears to be betraying the separatists in Ukraine but he does not want it to appear as if he betrays them.  I am not sure how long he can continue doing it before he gets into some trap that he himself has set up.  In the end, I think he will survive but very badly wounded.  Maybe then there will be a chance for some democratic changes.  I'll drink to that.

Ukrainians are not that smart when they make stupid comments like arresting Putin for illegal entry into Ukraine. Crimea has been Russian territory for hundreds of years and was only part of Ukraine for a short time due to an administrative change to borders which was not discussed with the locals when it was all part of Soviet Union when it didn't matter.

Here is the rub. Lavrov is pushing into territory not controlled by the Ukrainian Army, so theoretically this may be a way for Russia to cause an incident by having their own Russian terrorists shoot the convoy. So all is possible.

The word Police Force says it all.

By video games, cop shows and ultra militarized movies in combo with real life wars going on for 12 years in a row now, our land has descended into a mental spiral downwards that will be hard to reverse.

Dozens of African-American males have been killed by African-American males in Chicago this year.

Where are those protest marches? Where's the Twitter-verse?
Remember "Make Love not War?"

Teasing apart all of the components of the crisis in policing in the USA is more complex than Ferguson, MO. From sea to shining sea is that "force" is the pillar upon which rule by market forces rests.

Yes, obviously, racism is the giant pustulating horror that pervades the fabric of America's ugly past and sordid present. Ninety-nine of a hundred victims of sadistic, dehumanizing, smug police brutality are people of color.

Too-smart-for-their-britches racists in suits and ties with their very own channels in broadcast media fan indifference and contempt and save this monstrosity's place in polite society's bag of oh-so-rational excuses.

But there is much, much more.

Connect the dots. Homeless people are shot down, too. Dissenters are cracked over the head by eager white-shirted mobsters in New York City; shot at with tear gas canisters in Oakland, California; pepper-sprayed for the fun of it on college campuses.

Force.

Force, force, force.

Domestically and abroad. Enforcing the neoliberal project to steal every possible nickel from every possible worker, steal savings and homes with fine-print mumbo jumbo, impoverish whole nations, privatize the bases for a decent life for hundreds of millions of people.

Connect the dots.

Destroy foreign lands with force abroad. Destroy neighborhoods and kill people minding their own business at home.

You can fill in the blanks. It's not just Michel Brown -- may that unfortunate lad rest in peace.

There is plenty of humanitarian aid available.
Truckloads have arrived in Lugansk. Today a new planeload arrived from Canada. The Moscow Junta that caused this disaster should not be allowed to enter with its Trojan Horse called Humanitarian Aid.

And rabble who celebrates his death as "one less liberal" and insulting his grieving daughter in the same vein. Reading this from Europe, I am ashamed at what right wing extremism is turning the U.S.  into. I'm repulsed by these  pundits and their millions of ideological followers and happy I now live in my more civilized society far away.

My mother always said "if you have nothing nice to say, say nothing at all." It's good advice. Too bad that so many mean spirited, evil minded members of our public discourse don't abide by this.

I'd rather have the loving grateful memories of Robin Williams than the mean and hateful remembrances of Rush Limbaugh or Ann Coulter when I die.

I believe it comes from economic inequality and immobility. People wonder why celebrities live lives of such lavishness while people go hungry or without medical care. They wonder if their talent justifies their making such an outsized income.

There is a streak of meanness in American life today that is so horrific... the urge to build one's ego by destroying true talent - where does it come from? Life is tenuous enough... and talent so dependent upon attention to survive... to have to suffer fools like Rush Limbaugh.

This surely is a result of the end of the draft and the notion of that a civilian becomes a soldier and then returns to being a civilian again. Instead we have a class of well trained lifetime military enthusiasts and a public that is insulated from the real costs and risks of war.
They probably are the military (reservists, National Guard, veterans).

Jim, there is a boarder problem here.

Too many people who leave the military today have forgotten the maxim that they are citizens first and foremost.

A lesson that means that as a citizen your obligation is to leave behind the trappings of war.
Police officers who get a charge from acting as if they're military should resign and join our military
This can be answered by looking at the places that have already been liberated.

Ostensibly, Ukraine is a sovereign nation involved in a civil war with some of its own citizens. This theoretically means that the well-being of the noncombatants in the areas of conflict, Ukrainian citizens all, is the responsibility of the Ukrainian government. It seems that Kiev is treating everyone in the war zone as combatants, not as citizens with whom they will have to live in peace once the hostilities are finished. If Kiev prevails, what do they expect or want to happen to the population of southeastern Ukraine?

AND let me try to explain it again?
-(as there seems to be such a lot of confusion?)

'EUROPE IS NOT A BUNCH OF LOSER COUNTRIES'
And European economical policies are far more superior to the 'braindead' Boom and Bust policies of 'US'

And that is a fact - as not only 2008 has proven.
Where did the rebels weapons come from and how have they been getting into Russia? Why charade of aid convoy? Why not just ship the weapons and rebels the way they have?

Putin is incapable of anything humanitarian. He plays games with peoples lives and his militias which invaded eastern Ukraine have caused a lot of death and destruction. The convoy is probably carrying supplies for his militias and is meant as a distraction to stop effectiveness of Ukrainian forces in regaining their own territory from illegal takeover by Russian terrorists.
Besides, no foreign convoys can be permitted to enter Ukrainian territory without Ukrainian government approval. Even the Red Cross does not know what is in these trucks.
As for the murderous terror campaigns, these are being conducted by the Russian militias who are crooks. Porco Rosso - you have no evidence for your statements -these are only Putin's propaganda and one day he will be held responsible for the destruction he has caused.
You should be ashamed supporting the naked aggression of Russia.

What kind of "aid" convoy:

1. doesn't get permission to enter a foreign country?
2. doesn't say which border point it will be entering through?
3. invokes the name of the Red Cross, without a Red Cross endorsement?
4. has freshly painted white military trucks, straight from central casting?
5. is delivered by a country actively attacking the intended recipient?
6. has every photographed truck driver wearing exactly the same clothing?
7. is peppered with military personnel caring vehicles?
8. shows up when the rebels appear to be loosing and need "aid"?

I would not rely much on the globalresearch website. Plausible, but that is about it.

The silence from the USA government on the issue is a reasonably good sign that evidence now available, some public, points to an action by the Ukrainian military in the downing of the Malaysian Airlines airplane. Probably a series of errors, although who knows at this stage.

I suspect that the USA government was fully aware of this as soon as it happened, ergo the immediate finger pointing with no corroborating evidence, other than fabricated recordings and vague statements from Mr. Obama regarding a plume of exhaust, at the locals resisting the putschists' military attacks on them and of course further at the Russian military.

More lies, in a series of never-ending lies, from the USA and Ukrainian governments to cloud and deflect responsibility from the beginning appears to be the likeliest scenario at the moment.

You keep missing the point.
Ukraine is not looking to take possession of Russian Humanitarian Aid Trucks. The Red Cross is supposed to take charge of those trucks and take charge of distributing that aid.
The Ukrainian Government today turned over to the Red Cross some 100 trucks of humanitarian aid for Lugansk.
Unfortunately, Russia refuses to cooperate with the Red Cross. Why?
Because this convoy has nothing to do with Humanitarian Aid but is a ploy to buy time and allow Russian terrorists to regroup and receive weapons from Russia.

Many have written of Robin William's genius. There is no doubt that he possessed a towering intellect. That alone can cause one to feel out of place and left out. But he was much more. As the title states, "vulnerable showman." He was a performing artist. Unless a person has had any serious experience in the performance arts, be it singing, dancing or acting, it is virtually impossible to comprehend the massive amount of emotional energy the performer must generate. It takes superhuman strength to fill a large hall with your presence. And then do it again, night after night. The performer is giving all he or she has to give. They are completely exposed.

It is not possible for a dancer to fake their movements. Their feelings become their movements. The same goes for actors. They aren't pretending to feel emotion, they experience those emotions and share them with the world.

That's what Robin Williams did and he did it better and more intensely than just about anyone else. That's why he was such an incredible performer.

Robin Williams gave us all he had. The performer needs the audience to return his gift with their love and appreciation. Maybe he was too sick to feel our love. Maybe we didn't love him enough.

His life was a glorious gift to the world. I can't say that for those that ridicule him in death. Many years from now, the world will remember him with deepest affections. His detractors will be long forgotten.

"Many of them are Putin's Russia"

In fact, the "causes" have nothing to do with Russia whatsoever. The two primary causes are (1) the disastrous impact economically and socially of the collapse of the USSR with the concomitant contraction of economic activity of over 50% and (2) less so, but still significant, the highly noxious interference into Ukrainian internal affairs by the always disaster-causing group in the USA State Department and sundry other agencies involved in sowing mayhem in other countries of the world.

Mr. Putin and his associates stabilized Russia after the almost always intoxicated and often severely clinically depressed Boris Yeltsin followed the horrendous economic advice proffered by irresponsible USA and western European economic "advisers".

@Ivan Z
The EuroMaidan was a self-started organization that protested Yanukovich's walking away from a deal with the EU and making one with Russia--the West didn't start it. It became a popular uprising when Yanukovich used deadly force against it--the West didn't do that.

The civil war started when Russian-sponsored separatists with a largely Russian leadership started an armed uprising aimed at secession. This was after protests, partly filled by Russian citizens, that weren't for political reform but a Crimean-style referendum, a clear attempt at secession. They declared independence--a so-called "Donetsk People's Republic" and a so-called "Lugansk People's Republic" which declared a "Federal State of Novorossisk".

This was first provoked by Russian clients, first Yanukovich and then the separatists. Regarding who is a "marionette", it is telling that many of the separatist leaders are from Russia while all of the government leaders are from Ukraine.

"The majority of refugees (more than 700 000 by the official UN data) escaped from war to Russia."
That proves nothing except that the front is coming from the west so they mostly flee in the opposite direction. Further, being clients of a foreign state who started a secessionist uprising isn't one of "the right human values."

Your use of the term "genocide" is typical of your playing fast and loose with the truth on this issue.

Although there are undoubtably many Ukrainians sheltering in Russia, the huge number being reported as "official UN data" is in actuality being provided to the UN by the Russian government. The UN does not maintain any camps or have enough observers in Russia to count the number of "refugees". In the past when Russia claimed 200 000 or so Ukrainian refugees in Russia, much less than 20 000 had actually applied for refugee status. That 700 000 number is most likely exaggerated.

If I had been living in either Donetsk or Luhansk, I would have sought shelter somewhere else to escape the armed thugs that took over those cities myself, crossing to Russia if necessary to let the government troops do what was necessary to remove the criminals. I don't consider any large number of "refugees" in Russia to be an indictment against the Ukrainian government.

The Italians, the Portuguese, the Spanish and the Romanians are all "children of the same parent," the Roman Empire. Is there not one iota of difference between them? The English and the Irish were once part of the same British empire. Do they truly have "an equal hand in the darkness" of that empire?

Ukrainian and Russian languages began diverging with the fall of Kievan Rus' in the 13th century. Translators were needed at the negotiations for the Union of Pereyaslav which joined the eastern Ukrainian Cossack lands to Muscovia in the 17th century. The Ukrainian Cossacks had been free men for centuries. Now they and their descendants were mere subjects, bound to obey the ukazy that were made by distant rulers in Petersburg and Moscow.

Anyone who has bothered to learn this history knows that there is actually a great deal of difference between Ukrainians and Russians.

There is not one iota of difference between Russians and Ukrainians. They're children of the same parents. Both have an equal hand in the darkness of the Soviet past. Both view themselves as "great nations", and have grand visions of themselves combined with a massive inferiority complex.

Russia is guilty of encouraging a smouldering conflict that has regular people pay the price. Ukrainian tactic of a "siege", which starves the regular population of food and water, is completely barbaric.

I don't see involvement of the West in this conflict anything but self-serving. The anti-Russia agenda gives justification to the military-industrial complex, and there are resources in Ukraine some people (like Joe Biden's son) are eager to exploit.

Government spending can help when done wisely, but when they waste their money on stupid things like green energy, bailouts, Obamacare and assaults by the EPA and IRS; there is no return.  And don't forget regardless whether they spend wisely or wastefully you and I still have to pay for it.

Congress understands that government funds stimulate many local economies. Every legislator fights very hard to retain a military base or military production facility because the soldiers or employees stimulate all the local businesses. Congress' refusal to expand government spending to hire teachers, put laborers to work with infrastructure improvements, expand research facilities, etc. is hypocritical. Congress' refusal to assist with recovery of our economy has been far too limited. It has become cruel treatment of our long term unemployed, Their attitude fails to create a vision and hope for many young people. Time to vote for those who will support using the government resources to expand economic growth.

Many years ago, I witnessed the marvelous civility of an ordinary man named Joe. He was a volunteer crossing guard who was an example of courtesy and respect. He used a sense of humor to keep things light.

When he saw students preparing to jaywalk, he'd call out, "Gentlemen (Ladies), there's a crosswalk over here that would be honored by your presence." Sometimes it was, "a crosswalk over here that's lonesome for your presence". If a group were jostling to step off the curb before the light changed, he'd say, "One moment, please. I haven't laid down the red carpet." And then he'd wave the students across with a bow and a flourish as if he was unrolling a magnificent carpet before them.

He never barked orders, he never used harsh language, and he was never condescending. By using honorifics (gentlemen, ladies, young sir, young lady) and a demeanor that was pleasant, entertaining, and kind, he encouraged young people to follow his direction without feeling disrespected or demeaned.

It hurts to think that Michael Brown might be in his room studying tonight if only the policeman who'd addressed him and his friend had been as gallant as Joe. Yes, young people need to learn to be respectful and courteous, too. But it is us, the adults, who first set the example.

Anyone who works with the public needs to learn how to stay good humored and cordial under pressure. And how to see each face as a new face and a new soul, not someone to be judged by who came before.
That's it, just an assumption.  Let's let facts prevail.
My assumption is the US paid him to step down. We paid Karzai for years, so this would be chump change by comparison. (Pun intended)

How about cops not shooting unarmed black kids for jay walking? That would ensure that the crowds behave.

$360,000 for a truck! Taxpayers are taken for a ride by our lawmakers.

Sudhir:  Um, yeah.  This goes without saying.  When police show up dressed and equipped for violence, it's no surprise that they get violence.  Given the present situation, a plate of cookies would likely go a long way toward encouraging a constructive solution.  Of course, if police didn't behave like thugs in the first place, this event would not have happened and I wouldn't need to explain, to you and the 20 readers who (thus far) recommended your reply, one of the article's implications.  Your comment belabors the obvious and doesn't advance the conversation.

Tax payers have been taken for a ride far worst then this by the self interest , self righteous politicians and their cohorts, who misappropriate and mismanage trillions of dollars of tax payers money with impunity . Not to mention the absurdity of the US Supreme Court appointed for life. The 9 with average age 69. who each have five clerks , who do all the work. Plus these overlords , who dish out long winded absurd decisions, that corporations are people, only work 9 months a year and get paid for 12. Then on top of it all the five conservative republicans on the court have no common sense to read and interpret the two lines: " A well regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free States, the rights of the people to keep and bear arms, shall not be infringed"
The above is Article 11 , the so called 2nd amendment. That was adopted in 1791 and was for that particular era. When all farmers that is 80% of the people, shop keepers, etc. all belonged to States Militias. In case when trouble started, they were required to go sign out muskets etc armories way out place miles away and then go defend the free States . After that they were by law required to return these muskets or what ever to the armories. It was common sense and more practical for these folks of the militias to keep and bear arms around their homes / farms etc.
The way things are ending in this beguiled nation is that every citizen is deemed being the enemy and a terrorist.
A thought experiment....one could speculate on the crowds' response if police would instead show up bearing cool drinks and plates of chocolate chip cookies.

Advocating one policy or another is useless. The better the policy the less likely it is to be enacted in our sadly debased polity. The issue is process, not policy. We have a dysfunctional system. We need to figure out how to attack that system and the built in privelidge and entitlement upon which it rests.

Trolls should have their own spaces, but we should be able to filter them out so we do not have to hear them and have them disrupt our conversations.

One tactic that might work is to bother them by trying to reform them or talk to them about who they are. It might give some of them a reason to hesitate, and occasionally a real conversation about the meaning of our existence together might happen. The best thing to do about trolls is to convince them to cut down on their activity and find some other way to get what they get out of trolling.

As you say, "avoid war" and "update our infrastructure". With these two moves, we will have taken money spent on guns and put them to "butter." In other words, thrown money that was spent on destruction at creation instead. Remember the old bumper sticker, "what if the military had to run bake sales?" Not a bad plan.

"My formula for prosperity is too avoid war, update our infrastructure, relieve student debt, and provide a free college education to all."

In other words, Keynesian stimulus.

And halting inflation actually *is* pretty easy. You have the fed raise the interest rate for a year or two. That can cause a sharp recession, but as soon as inflation is controlled and rates are lowered again, things bounce back. (This is basically the story of "Morning in America", the growth boom that followed Volcker's arrest of the '70s inflation problems.) And given that we all know the history, it's quite plausible that an inflation-arresting reset of expectations would be less damaging now than it was in the early '80s.

In any case, crushing the economy under obviously inadequate demand in order to avoid the hypothetical specter of too much demand is kind of insane. It's like saying, "If I give this man with sepsis penicillin, I might over-dose him, and then he'd die of penicillin poisoning! So I must sit on my hands and let the infection continue to spread." Or, even worse, "I must give him only minimal / inadequate doses that will allow the infection to develop antibiotic resistance." The equivalent of Japan's start/stop response to its deflation crisis, or the stimulus we had in the US, which was less than half of what experts recommended -- it helped a little, temporarily, but because it didn't fully solve the problem, further action faces steeper political hurdles.
Easy? Ask Paul Volcker.

Once the fires of inflation begin to burn they are not be put out so easily. Yes, we are in an extended period of slow growth, but if the economy picks up, for some unforeseen reason, a technological breakthrough, a sea of oil in the Nevada desert, or even better, a settlement of the Arab-Israeli crisis, and we are close to full employment, the need for labor can grow and grow quickly. Prices will rise, wages will rise and they will spiral. I understand the malaise in which we now find ourselves, the disappointment of many because opportunity is limited, but if we enter the boom/bust cycle again the effects would be far more destructive. Just like a crash in the market, it takes a generation until investors forget the real danger, and the same applies to inflation. My opinion, based purely on intuition, not data, is simply that in economics, small increments of growth is the desired outcome; less is more. My formula for prosperity is too avoid war, update our infrastructure, relieve student debt, and provide a free college education to all. Throwing money at the problem is not the answer.

'in the US and the UK, we're going back to the future; rebuilding a Finance economy that is not just prone to boom and bust, but built for it.'

That's what I'm sayen - we need more subprime loans!
-(back to the back!)
